The plant produces small, spike-like inflorescences bearing tiny, greenish flowers that are often clustered closely together. Selenodesmium elongatum is native to certain regions of Africa and is adapted to grow in dry, open habitats. Due to its limited distribution and specific ecological requirements, it is considered a rare and potentially endangered species.
